titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Renée Levine Packer Papers, 1963-circa 2015
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by John Bewley.

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of personal and research papers belonging to Renée Levine Packer, including correspondence and files for her books: This life of sounds and Gay Guerrilla. It also includes recordings of interviews conducted by Levine-Packer for her book research as well as inscribed books and commercial recordings.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], Renée Levine Packer Papers, 1963-circa 2015, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Renée Levine Packer, August 2015.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: Additional materials related to research on Julius Eastman for the book, Gay Guerrilla are expected to be sent.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Renée Levine Packer (née Wennerholm) was born in Nice, France and raised in New York and Mexico City. After working at the Dance Department at The Juilliard School and at the national headquarters of Young Audiences, Inc., Levine Packer moved to Buffalo, New York in 1964 after her husband, Jesse Levine, attained the position of principal viola with the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra for the 1964-1965 season. Lukas Foss and Allen Sapp created the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts at the State University of New York at Buffalo using funds from the Rockefeller Foundation. The first year of operation was 1964 and the Center was soon in need of a coordinator and manager to handle all the details concerning the fellows of the Center, known as Creative Associates, as well as all the logistics involved with producing concerts in Buffalo, New York City, and elsewhere. Levine Packer was hired in January 1965 as an assistant to Richard Wernick. When Wernick left in spring of 1965, Levine Packer was hired as Center Coordinator. She served in that title until 1974 when she also became the Center's Managing Director until her departure in 1978.

Levine Packer left the University at Buffalo in 1978 to go to the California Institute of the Arts (Cal Arts) to serve as Director of Admissions and Records until 1982. While at Cal Arts Renée also served as Director of Contemporary Music Festival. Following her work at Cal Arts, Levine Packer moved to Washington, D.C. to work as the Director of the Inter-Arts Program at the National Endowment for the Arts 1982-1986. from 1986-1993, Levine Packer worked as an independent arts consultant and producer. In this role she was responsible for a production of Robert Longo's theater work, Killing Angels in 1987 at Buffalo State College and a production of Steve Reich and Beryl Korot's video-opera The Cave in 1993. She also conducted a national survey on alternative arts organizations in the United States for the Ford Foundation and conducted a survey and wrote a report for Georgetown University concerning the creation of a performing arts center and program of public performances. Levine Packer served as Dean of Continuing Studies at the Maryland Institute, College of Art 1992-2000.

Renée Levine Packer's educational background includes earning a B.A. degree in arts administration from the State University of New York Empire State College and attendance at the Harvard Institute of Arts Administration in 1973. She earned a Master of Liberal Arts degree from Johns Hopkins University in 2001. She began her research on the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts as part of her studies at Johns Hopkins, writing her thesis, In the Center: The Center of the Creative and Performing Arts in the State University of New York at Buffalo, as her thesis. The thesis then served as the basis for her Oxford University Press book, This Life of Sounds: Evenings for New Music in Buffalo (2010). Levine Packer's next book project was Gay Guerrilla: Julius Eastman and His Music (University of Rochester Press, 2015), which she conceived and for which she served as co-editor with Mary Jane Leach and contributor of the major biographical chapter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the papers of author and arts administrator Renée Levine Packer. It includes a small number of personal documents, such as résumés, and personal correspondence. The majority of the content was created in the process of writing This Life of Sounds: Evenings for New Music in Buffalo, and writing and editing Gay Guerrilla: Julius Eastman and His Music. Also included are working files for Levine-Packer's rôle as producer of performances of Robert Longo's Killing Angels and Steve Reich and Beryl Korot's The Cave. Additional content includes clippings, programs, photographs, cassette recordings of interviews for both books, signed books and recordings.

There is considerable overlap within the collection. For example, composer John Cage is represented as a subject, a correspondent, as an author and composer, and by a series of folders of contents collected by Levine Packer for other purposes. The collection was chiefly received within folders with titles by the creator. The contents of the folders were maintained and titles were kept wherever feasible. Dates for folder contents are supplied where easily discerned.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in twelve series:

item.ref: II. Book, interview, and research files for This Life of Sounds
III. Production files for Robert Longo's Killing Angels
IV. Production files for Steve Reich and Beryl Korot's The Cave
XII. Book, interview, and research files for Gay Guerrilla: Julius Eastman and His Music

arrangement.p:
Arranged in two subseries:
A. Personal documents
B. Writings

scopecontent.p: Contains small number of self-written biographical sketches, résumés, and clippings about Levine Packer.
Contains some of Renée Levine Packer's writings, included unpublished texts. Dates are supplied when known.

Book, interview, and research files for This Life of Sounds
1963-2011

scopecontent.p: Contains all the files and interview recordings associated with the book, This Life of Sounds and the master's thesis on which it was based, In the Center: The Center of the Creative and Performing Arts in the State University of New York at Buffalo. There is no attempt at separation of the documentation concerning the thesis versus the published book since many of the files were used for both.

arrangement.p:
Arranged into seven subseries:
A. Book content files
B. Book business files
C. Interview transcriptions and correspondence
D. Subject files
E. Supplementary University at Buffalo Music Library Catalogs and University at Buffalo publications about student unrest
F. Interview recordings
G. Electronic files for book and interview transcriptions

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains folders related to the genesis of the text.
Content related to the publication and marketing of the book, as well as expenses, permissions, and comments from peer review readers.

did.unittitle: Correspondence: State University of New York Press

scopecontent.p: The interviews were originally conducted for the thesis version of the text where the transcriptions were included as an appendix. The folders in some cases include correspondence and printouts of email. Some interviewees were only contacted via email rather than recorded in person.

arrangement.p: Alphabetically arranged by interviewee surname, with lists at the beginning.

scopecontent.p: Contains the subject research files for the book. Note that folders for personal names may contain correspondence, material treating the person as a subject, or articles by the person. The range of dates represents when the material was collected, not the date of the original documents. There are 24 folders related to the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts and another 13 folders of clippings about Center events. The Rockefeller Foundation was the original source of funding for the Center and is represented by 11 folders of content. For the most part, folder content has been maintained as received.

Schrag, Carl: Searching for Abraham and Ibrahim -- 1991-02-06 : Times (London). Gray, Louise: Identity parade in an ancient cave: minimalist composer Steve Reich looks to his roots for inspiration -- 1993? Baltimore Jewish Times. Greenberg, Melinda: Cave explorations -- 1993-05-19 : Times (London). Griffiths, Paul: Voices in search of harmony: a Steve Reich premiere in Vienna -- 1993-05--1993-10. Compilation from multiple sources -- 1993-05-29 : International Herald Tribune. Rockwell, John: Vienna Festival: Much more than waltzes -- 1993-06 : Magazine of The Netherlands Holland Festival -- 1993-06-11 : Guardian. Sweeting, Adam: Tiers of despair -- 1993-06-12 : Financial Times (London). Clements, Andrew: A cave full of treasures -- 1993-06-14 : New York Times. Kozinn, Allan: Next Wave Festival to open with premiere -- 1993-06-14 : Time Magazine. Walsh, Michael: Words sliced and diced -- 1993-08-20 : Guardian. Bowen, Merion: The Reich stuff: Steve Reich's ground-breaking The Cave at the RFH -- 1993-08-21 : Times (London). Brunskill, Ian: Sounds with vision -- 1993-08-29 : Observer (London). Porter, Andrew: Music -- 1993-09-12 : New York Times Magazine. Woodward, Richard B. : Songs of a wired cave -- 1993-10 : Opera News. Schwarz, K. Robert: Witnesses -- 1993-10-10 : New York Times. Schwarz, K. Robert: The Cave walks, but doesn't quack, like an opera -- 1993-10-12 : USA Today. Stearns, David Patrick: Politics resonate in The Cave -- 1993-10-15 : New York Newsday. Stuart, Jan: Seeds of Arab-Israeli conflict in The Cave -- 1993-10-21 : Le Nouvel Observateur. Anquetil, Gilles: Les chants d'Abraham -- 1993-10-28 : Le Soir. Debrocq, Michel: Steve Reich et Beryl Korot donnent naissance au videopera -- 1993-10-29 : Le Monde. Rey, Anne: Proposition d'operas -- 1993-11-02 : Village Voice. Taruskin, Richard: A sturdy musical bridge to the 21st century -- 1999-07-17 : New York Times. Oestreich, James W. : Reich's amalgam of speech and melody -- 2006-11-04 : New York Times. The correspondence with Betty Freeman is followed by some ancillary material because she is not represented elsewhere in the collection.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog.
